description.text: Using this, The center of Z-axis respect with Y-axis is easy to set up.

Sometimes if I'm printing one print after the other I don't like to wait for everything to cool
down. Seems like a waste of energy. So I keep a spare glass plate handy, and ready, so I
can swap it in place and continue on to the next print.
I made this holder for two glass plates. They are held at a slight angle in case I have them
coated with Elmer's glue so they don't rub up against the side of the tray.
This assumes you have glass plates that are fairly close tolerance to one another as my
two are.
I've included the Cubify Design file in case someone wants to modify it and also the
Simplify 3D factory file if you use that slicer.
You should give the plate a chance to warm up before printing.

I made mine at 0.2mm layer height, 15 percent infill. Used white PLA. Printed it vertically, its a full 8 inches so don't get scared if it looks like the bed is going to bottom out. :)
Actually I think its like 7.98 or something like that (200mm)

description.text:
I fixed the annoying issue of having to plug/unplug the power cord every time I wanted to print something in my Solidoodle 2 printer.
I used the 4 screws meant to hold the filament original support.
To avoid any soldering temper I'm using a male-to-male adapter I made myself to hook up my switch panel into the main board.
I used a snap-in on the cover mechanism that turned out a little hard to fit in and I did some amount of sanding the brim to make it fit. Before exporting the STL file I did tweak the brim so I never tested the final-final design.
Please share your experience.

• Print both STL files (box and cover)
  • Do some soldering work to create the connections between switch and both in and out female power plugs.
  • Make sure you attach the cover in before start screwing things on (I made that mistake.... twice)
  • Screw them in the holes
  • Before closing the lid, screw in the 4 allen screws from the back spool original support (of course I replaced that support for something else!)
    Have fun!

title: Frankenmiata, Enterprise Themed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 1/24 scale model of Eyesore Racing's Frankenmiata, a racecar that they welded together out of a couple of wrecked NA MX-5 Miatas. Eyesore is a legendary team in 24 Hours of LeMons racing (not a typo, it's an American budget endurance racing series, not the big fancy race in France) not just for building winning cars, but for introducing the concept of themed builds that led to the circus-like atmosphere found in LeMons paddocks today. You can read more about them here:
http://blog.caranddriver.com/because-lemons-legends-dont-just-win-races-the-amazing-cars-and-costumes-of-eyesore-racing/
http://www.motoiq.com/Projects/Mazda/Frankenmiata.aspx This is a project that I started thinking about as soon as I finished the other Miata, but put on the back burner a few times, most recently in October when I experienced a long series of print failures that I couldn't pin down to a problem with an extruder, filament, or the model. I wasn't planning on trying it again until spring, but decided to get it done this week because of the theme

Print one of each part, except the pins (10), wheels (4), and nacelle support struts (2). The body, engine, engine intake, dish, nacelles, and rollcage main hoop (part1) should be printed with support. The windshield is meant to be printed in transparent material.

Customizeable, fillable weights!
Print your own weight set, and fill with water, sand, pennies, or lead shot. Designed to be printable on any printer with a 6"x6" bed. Height requirements may vary.
Note: The weights are not compensated for the weight of the plastic, which can change with infill and printing material. Fill accordingly.

• Click the button labeled "Open in Customizer."
  • Select a fill material (water, sand, pennies, or lead shot)
  • Select a weight type (dumbell or kettle)
  • Choose your weight (in pounds or kilograms)
  • Select your export mode for printing
  • Print while drinking protein shake
  • Fill the weight container with your chosen material
  • Screw the container onto the handle
  • Pump iron (or water, pennies, etc.)

comments.text:
about wobble:
At my K8200 I had much Z-wobble. And I have found out this: Standard M8 nuts are not in 90deg angle between surface and thread. If you tighten the nuts your M8 rod will be bend. Then you have much wobble. I have fixed this problem by using long (25mm) nuts. Also the rod has to be changed to a new one. It is not 100% of the solution but metal coupler and bad nuts will not solve the problem.
comments.author: faggahz

comments.text: I am using a smooth rod in place of the threaded rod and using threadless leadscrews for the head this avoids the problems.
comments.author: faggahz

comments.text: Do you have a video?
comments.author: Gil

comments.text: http://youtu.be/iRSXKnYOBeo
comments.author: Gil

comments.text: Nice! I also experience wobble in my robot arms even with metal couplers. I think the rods are to blame.
comments.author: pghauff

comments.text:
It is the 608 bearings they dont fit the M8 threaded rod....I transfered to a threadless leadscrew system with rotary encoder for feedback. Less wobble so far. I will keep you updated when I test it.
Thanks
comments.author: Gil

Thanks for your input Redsic. I am looking to redesign the arm soon and purchasing 12mm smooth rod for extra ridgidity and not buy them from china to ensure precision. Reduction of wobble is super critical. I will be revisiting this design soon so keep an eye out for upcoming changes.
Thanks Pamela

Lamp shade 500mm to 700mm wide, depending on scale of print.

Print quantity required:
55 Pendant Lamp Shade (1 of 2)
5 Pendant Lamp Shade (2 of 2) - last ones to install - where power cable is thread through.
The ones shown in the photo were printed at 90% scale. I have also printed one at 100% scale and one at 125% scale. Each one takes about one hour to print so it takes a while.
The long part has 5 objects attached to it so it uses the 8mm length M3 screws. The other 4 arms use the 6mm length M3 screws.
The Power connectors are threaded through the last 5 (Pendant Lamp Shaded 2 of 2) and I drilled a 2.75mm hole through both pieces then used a steel m3 screw to make a thread and then used one of the plastic 6mm M3 screws to hold the wire cable in position.
You will need to buy a lamp cable to fit through the lamp shade.
Files were made in tinkercad.

description.text:
This is a bench dog for the Harbor freight 60" workbench (http://www.harborfreight.com/60-inch-workbench-93454.html).
This bench dog provides for a 1/4-20 nut. I use these for strapping down benchtop machines and for various jigs. (example hardware: http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?c=&cat=1,43455&p=61994)
print hex slot up on 0.3mm, 3 shells, at least 15% infill

comments.text: Fitting these I found that it works best if you insert the dog from below and use a saddle washer larger that the hole in the bench. Thread a 2"ish long 1/4-20 bolt with a solid head on it that you can use the pull the nut up into the dog and flush it with the bench. Don't overdo it. I had some sketchup annoyances with this model and might redo it with better dimensions as its a finnicky fit.

description.text:
These are outer pieces that fit onto Hoeken's original twisted triangle.  (both square and circular)
No useful application, just fun and cool to play with!

NOTES!!!

  • SCALE THE OBJECT. the STL given should be exactly the size of hoeken's twisted triangle; HOWEVER, due to slight blobbiness or whatever, I recommend scaling the outer triangle to about 1.04->1.08 times the original size. That way the outer triangle will fit very snug around the inner object.
    (i believe mine is ~1.06x, and it fits perfect)

  • The STL file may look like one side is covered; not sure why, but it should print regularly
    (or print the MaskedRetriever's version which doesn't have this problem!)

This is a stylus that I made for a friend of mine who had lost the one in his NDS lite. This one fits rather nicely into the DS lite\'s dedicated stylus slot, and works very well on its touch screen. I\'m sure you can use it on other screens, as well.

This works best when printed at a slight angle (say, 10Ëš) to the raft, like you see in the .stl version. The .blend version uploaded here is parallel to the raft, which leads to threads getting loose and breaking off if printed verbatim.
After you print this, it works best if you sand the tip into a slightly rounder shape. Apply spray paint if you like - might make the surface smoother, and give it a better look as well.

title: Prime Monolith Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is my first contribution here. It is a 2001-style prime monolith set. It is 2001-style because the monolithsâ€™ dimensions are 1:4:9, the squares of the first three positive integers, just like the monoliths in 2001 A Space Odyssey. The monoliths are prime because their depths in millimeters are prime numbers, namely 5 mm, 7 mm, and 11 mm. There are three of them, which is a prime number as well. I do not own a 3D printer and I did not use any design software to create them, just pure mathematics. Unfortunately, that means I cannot test whether I created the right STL file (especially, I am not absolutely sure I am using the x-, y-, and z-axes correctly). If you print it, please mention it in a comment, so I know I did it right. And if you cannot print it, mention that as well, so I know I need to fix it. Have fun!

Print on a 3D printer, which can print 100 mm by 100 mm on its base. The monoliths are not that big, but there are three of them. Please use black material, since that is the color of the monoliths. description.text: This project was made so that you could make binaural recordings which are recordings that are very realistic sounding. These recordings are only realistic sounding because they are recorded in a similar way that people hear sound. Also these recordings are only realistic sounding when listening with good headphones. An example of a binaural recording done with this thanks to Shepshepard (http://www.thingiverse.com/Shepshepard/about) is: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0SBl5bnDX8Q&feature=youtu.be I'm designer for shapeways here: https://www.shapeways.com/designer/jonathanmarch/hire-me

First: Print the parts
Settings: for the ear and side parts make then 25% hollow or more
(quanity)partname
(1) main_body.stl
(1) top.stl
(2) side_parts.stl
(1) nut_holder.stl
(1) thumb_screw_top.stl
(1) ear_left.stl
(1) ear_right.stl
Second: Buy Parts
(2) 1/4" nuts
(1) 1/4" hex bolt
(1) stereo microphone
http://www.azden.com/products/microphones/lapel-microphones/ex-503/ (similar ones were used, two of them wired together to stereo)
Optional: cotton balls
Third: Assemble (should be easy)
Glue a 1/4" nut in the bottom of the main_body
Glue a 1/4" nut in the nut_holder
Glue the nut_holder in the main_body at the top
Glue the thumb_screw_top to a 1/4" hex bolt
Glue the ears onto the side_parts (the angle of the ears should be close and the holes should line up fairly close too)
Feed microphones into the main_body
Insert microphones into the side_parts left mic with left ear ect.
Insert side_parts into main_body
Optional: fill main_body with cotton balls
Put the top on the main_body
Insert the screw through the top and tighten (not too tight)

title: printed mold for silicone hot liquid pump (artificial heart) and pinch valve

description.text:
the tpe mold does not work. it seems the silicone will not cure when in contact with tpe. so printed the mold with abs and hips. need to break the inner part of the mold. the outer part is re-usable. the heart chambers can be driven with a servo or SMA. servo use far less power hungry and offers more control. the servo is placed in between 2 of the pumps (with a one way valve on each end), this will make a 2-chamber 4-valve heart. i made a vacuum chamber out of a 12v dc car air pump and a glass jar for the silicone. better than none.
update 16th Oct 2014: the duck bill valve works but not fell short of expectation. made valve1016, a design copied from the pulmonary semilunar valve of a human heart. can drill a few hole through the inner part or the mold to form silicone chordae tendineae if very soft molding silicone is used or larger servo is used. i use 4kg/cm servo.
update 18thOct2014:
heartvalve1016 works, performance not ideal. wall too thin. valve edge design fault (inside out). updated with heartvalve1018
end connector section for SMA arteryend1017 uploaded update 18 Nov 2014
on the request from breye, uplaoded more pic. new heart valve. put the valve on each end, facing the same direction, clue with silicon. unless you what to try to grown tissues as lining or use the thing as support for growing tissues, or use part of organs like intestine or make one cavity with types of tissues, and drive with servo or low temp SMA, a rotary type of pump might be a better option. but i believe low temp (around 40 degree c) SMA with none contact (inductive) activation is a viable idea and worth trying for artificial hearts. comparing with motors, SMA is a lot lot lighter and smaller, maintenance free and last for ever (used within temperature and stress range) while a motor will eventually worn out . the down side is sma will drain a battery faster than motors for the same work. since i do not have a vacuum or compress chamber, i have difficulty pouring bubble-free silicone parts. I printed one with tpe, great, but can not match the heat resistance property of silicone. and worse, i have found out the silicone will not cure when in contact with tpe. i still think the silicone heart pump would be a better choice for implants. i do not want to invest in vacuum or compress chamber for silicone, so i am milling my high temp pump with aluminium or delrin. unlike the heart pump, these rotary pumps are not in one piece, requiring seals, not fully sealed like a heart pump, will not be as durable, however will serve my project well for now. hope this will help, Breye.

description.text:
These DC-DC converters are great, they are very cheap (~$3), and over 90% efficient. 
I use them for powering my Raspberry Pis which I mount to a DIN rail on the end of my desk to keep them out of the way (see my RPi DIN Rail mount thingi). 
After getting fed up with duct taping my DC converters to my desk I decided it was high time to design & print a DIN rail housing for them too...

I printed this at 0.15mm on my Up! Plus printer but it should print well at lower resolutions (0.2-0.3mm). The top section can be printed without a support structure but the base section will need one.

A spool holder designed to fit on the 1lb spool that comes with the MakerBot Replicator 2 and hold unspooled filament such as Faberdashery PLA filament.

Clip 3 of these spool holder parts onto a 1lb MakerBot material spool like the ones that ship with the Replicator 2. Make sure all of the printed clips are on the side of the spool furthest from the machine to stop it catching the parts on the back of the Bot. You will also want to mount the spool on the left hand side of the Bot, when viewed from the front (opposite side of the Bot to the power switch), so that it does not catch the power cable. As this will be a larger diameter than the usual spools you can leave the filament guide tube on the right hand side, when viewed from the front, of the extruder cable. This will hold unspooled plastic filament like the filament available from Faberdashery.
This part was designed and tested on the Replicator 2 using Faberdashery material .

This is a non-metallic alignment tool, aka "tweaker", aka "diddle stick."   One end is a flat blade for adjusting trimmer capacitors, the other is a hexagon for adjusting tuning coils.  Hex shape keeps it from rolling off your workbench.

Updated version of my previous Bowden conversions for the wooden Printrbot Simple (2013). [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217094 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:305215].
I have been using this version for a number of months now and it seems to work pretty well (for me at least). Includes a removable fan deflector/shroud to allow the fan to cool the hotend tube as well as the hotend output.
Includes an extruder spacer to allow the existing extruder bolts to work when the extruder and motor are not fitted to the printer.
Includes friction mount connectors for the PTFE tube to avoid the need to purchase push to fit fittings. [This idea is attributable to someone, but i cant find the reference - sorry].
Extruder fitting is an adaptation of the Internal filament guide for Printrbot direct drive extruder by rswarner.
The Hotend fitting is an adaptation of one of the fittings in Printrbot Simple Bowden conversion by owens to make it fit the new extruder location.
Note: The Simple in the pictures also has my X-Axis extension http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:305229 fitted with a perspex print bed (covered in blue painters tape).

Print 1 of each component.
The hotend block screws into existing holes at the end of the Simple Y axis arm and the hotend mounts using the existing screws. New screws are needed to attach the block.
The printed fan mount fits using one of the screws used to attach the hotend block. The shroud attaches on the lower side of the fan mount, with the screws from the fan passing through both parts.
The extruder fitting replaces the hollow plastic tube and the small wooden component in the extruder assembly..
The new extruder support fitting requires printing 1x spacer.
The hole through the hotend block corner is to allow the cables to be cable wrapped as per the normal setup. There is also an extra screw hole in the block to allow the hotend to be firmed up if it isnt firm initially.
Additional components needed:
2x 25mm (or longer) M3 bolts with nuts will be required to attach the hotend component (i used wing nuts).
Small spring clamp for extruder fitting.
PTFE tube (4mm outer, 2mm inner) - About a foot should do. Note: The friction fittings require the tube to be pushed in from the side and shouldn't allow the tube to move within the fitting. If movement occurs try packing with a bit of sandpaper or similar. I have found that without something to hold the 'top' end of the tube in the fitting in place it tends to work its way loose. I have tried two solutions for this (both of which work), one is a wire twisted around the fitting and tube (as shown in the hotend fitting pictures) and the other is to print a 'clip' to fit over the tube and fitting (as shown in the extruder fitting pictures). Note: The print file for the extruder fitting clip contains a number of slightly different sized clips - i just print them all and then see which one fits best.
As you can see from the pictures i use a small clamp to squeeze the extruder mount - this is not printed, i bought it. It is possible to use the existing spring mechanism, but i found this easier to fit and remove.

comments.text: The PTFE tubing is slipping out of the extruder fitting. What should I do?
comments.author: May0

comments.text: I have used a small piece of sandpaper wrapped around the tube (sandy side to the tube) to produce a tighter fit when I had slippage. It doesn't need to wrap all the way around, just enough to produce a tighter fit. A little experimentation may be required. Other types of paper etc may work, I just happened to have sandpaper handy (I use it to roughen the print bed paper).

description.text:

Brighten up your militaristic Halloween costume with an illuminated bandolier made from NinjaFlex 3D printing filament and a strip of glowing NeoPixels. These are (potentially sapphire) bullets of pure love. Full tutorial: https://learn.adafruit.com/bandolier-of-light
Edit and modify the design in Autodesk 123D Design:
http://www.123dapp.com/project/Bandolier%20of%20Light/2924994

We recommend printing the STLs in NinjaFlex flexible filament. The design is optimized to print with no support material.
For the best quality when printing with NinjaFlex, we recommend the following slicing settings:
Retraction: Off
Speeds: 45/50
Extruder Temp: 230c
Infill 10%
Raft+Support: Off
No Heated Bed
The print may include some string artifacts during the printing process. These bits of string and easily to remove with a pair of sharp scissors. Tug on the bits of material and ship them away to remove the excess material.
The original solids where created in Autodesk 123D Design and are available to customize to match your costume. You can edit the model directly inside your browser or the 123D desktop app:

description.text: An automatic coin sorter for many currencies. See also http://youtu.be/7F2fIF9PNBk for a short demo video. To store a coin, you may release a coin from the rightmost top, and it will slide down the hill and go into the right tube. To get a coin, you may pull the whole rack out and take out any coin.

These instructions below are especially for Ultimaker2 printer and Cura software. Please adjust any parameter as needed if you are using other software.

  • Use 'normal' quality. Or if you're an export, consider using the settings provided below.

  • Print the top board ???-Sorter-topboard.stl.

    • Cura expert settings:
      • Layer height = 0.1mm,
      • Shell thickness = 2.4mm,
      • Bottom/top thickness = 1.5mm.
    • Print!

  • Print the base box ???-Sorter-box.stl.

    • Cura expert settings:
      • Layer height = 0.1mm,
      • Shell thickness = Bottom/top thickness = 1.2mm.
    • Tune retraction settings at the printer:
      • Retraction length = 3mm.
    • Print!

  • Print the tubes ???-Sorter-tubes.stl. Same settings as step 3.

  • Put them together. Done!

comments.text:
I'm sorry for this, Randy.
It's basically true that small coins fall out of the front quite frequently. This is because the "opening" have to be wide to allow the fingers picking coins from the tubes. I'm now designing a next-gen coin sorter which has a spiral "coin way" and a "wall" that prevent the coins to fall out.
However, for "wrong tubes 10% of the time", I haven't met with such issue in the CHF version. This may because the coin radius difference is relatively smaller among USD coins. When I have a chance to go to the US I'll try to test it myself.
After all, thank you for trying my model!

description.text: abs 1.75 4h

This concept was my submission for the Makerbot Replicator 2 Design Challenge.  
In the year 2040 it is expected for autonomous vehicles to be commonplace. There are, however, countless individuals who cannot live without a fundamental driving experience. As material sciences and technologies vastly advance in the next few decades, astounding new vehicle designs are possible.  
This concept features a rigid, lightweight construction and is entirely operated with by-wire technology. The electronic steering and propulsion systems allow for an intuitive, direct experience. As well, the suspended seats rotate with the car when turning for enhanced visibility. The driver is directly connected to the road.
Will provide part files soon. In the meantime, enjoy the full model!

remixed_from.title: 2 Liter Bottle Holder with Funnel and Cap

description.text: As an exercise in learning Fusion 360, I have made this bottle neck that conforms to the PCO-1881 standard, used in many modern 2L bottles. If you just want to interface to bottles, I suggest you use laird's model.

I don't know why anyone would want to print this thing, but if you were determined to, the best way is to print it in two halves horizontally and glue them together. Printing in one piece may be problematic because of the overhangs. You will need support for the interior arch.
I have not provided a split model, but with most platers you can do a quick and dirty split by copying the model, rotating one, and dropping both below the bed so that the bed is at your desired parting line. Place the parting line so that it is 90 degrees from the thread start.

A heart pendant I designed for my wife. It started as the basis for a heart puzzle but evolved into this. Spent way too long figuring out different ways to do it but here it is just in time for Valentines day!
Updated 2/16/13 as I realized I had uploaded an older STL. This one prints the ring much easier as it's slightly larger and better positioned.

I printed at .15mm layer height. 10% infill, and 2 shells. My prototypes varied from .30mm to 0% infill and 0-3 shells. They all worked but it all depends on your printer and how it's going to do with the ring. Just print the plate and super glue it together!
Good luck!

title: PublicLaboratory Mobile Spectrometer v3.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Here it is. Version 3.0 of the PublicLaboratory.org mobile spectrometer. This spectrometer is a scientific tool that straps onto an Android or iOS phone, tablet, or any camera capable of focusing very close (macro-mode) and allows you to collect spectra. Why would you want one? You can use it to identify the elemental composition of things (light bulbs, olive oil, beer, etc) based on the colors of light they emit. You can even use it to monitor your home brewing progress (http://bit.ly/Xyor6B).

Version 4.0 will be released very soon and is a much more refined design. You can read more about it here: http://publiclaboratory.org/notes/braddudenhoffer/2-11-2013/evolution-plots-smartphone-spectrometer-0 Assembly is much easier than earlier models.
  • Print the two parts (the base and the body either plain or with the logo)
  • Attach a film grating to the upper side of the base
  • Secure the base to the body with hot glue, tape, or if you print with ABS by solvent welding it together with acetone.
  • Mount it to your phone
  • Use spectralworkbench.org to calibrate, save, and share your spectra. There is a native iOS app in the works but I can't say for sure when it will be released.
    • If you use an extrusion printer such as a Mendel you will probably need to print with support if you want the text to show up. If anybody wants a version without the text, let me know and I will post it ASAP. Also, make sure you have your printer tuned up to print bridges and overhangs very well, because this thing is basically one huge overhang. I have successfully printed it on a MendelMax. The walls are little thinner than is ideal but that will be fixed in the next version :). All parts have been NetFabbed and verified.
    This is the grating I have used for the prototype. It is the linear style with 1000lines per mm: tinyurl.com/9tjrz8r . You can also use the film off of a CD, DVD, or BluRay as seen here: http://publiclaboratory.org/tool/spectrometer License: CERN OHL v1.1 Public Lab contributors
    http://www.publiclaboratory.org/tool/spectrometer

comments.text: Hello Vise. Thank you for trying out the spectrometer. What type of phone are you using? The spectra don't need to be perfectly centered as long as they are consistent. The analysis software uses a row of the camera sensor that is only a couple pixels wide so cutting the top off won't affect anything. If you want one to fit a specific model of phone you might want to take a look at version 2.3 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28100)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... It is about the same length but half as wide. The length does have a strong effect on geometry and spectrum spread. This one is about as short as is usable without some fancy lenses, mirrors, and grating. Phones with a larger/wider lens would benefit from a longer distance from the slit to the sensor.

comments.text: For absorbance scpectroscopy just about any light source can be used as long as it is consistent. White LEDs work well enough but tungsten lamps are generally better. Emission spectroscopy can also be done with just about any light source but lasers are becoming more popular than other techniques. In general, you excite with one wavelength of light wand watch for changes in another. Metals can be tough. You need to superheat them if you want to measure them directly.  There are reagents which quantitatively great with specific metals and then have a color change or shift which could be used with this spectrometer.

I've had some experience with inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy for detecting trace metals in a water sample. (the samples would need to go thru an acid digestion step)
I wonder if this process could be scaled down to a handheld unit? However the argon gas and the strong magnetic field needed to create the plasma may be speed bumps to say the least. Still... the processing power of a smartphone could be applied to the process in some way.

comments.text: Having had an ICP apart, I doubt thee will be a portable version any time soon. LIBS is the future for that type of thing. description.text:
This fork holder is designed for people with limited mobility to create a customizable eating utensil. Using this fork holder and handle and some easily obtainable parts such as 1/2" PVC pipe and a rubber band, this assistive device can be used to manipulate a fork while keeping your hands below table level. Unlike other overly complex assistive devices, it requires no screws or power. The handle is designed to support traditional and nontraditional gripping strategies.  
I have used and relied on this design daily to eat independently since 2012. It's taken many redesigns to get it just right: to print without support, to be light-weight, and to print on small printers, but I am very satisfied with it. It looks more attractive than other designs I've used made by occupational therapists, and can be fully taken apart to be cleaned. Every fork I've tried has fit well, from plastic to heavy dinnerware. This design alone has made a 3-D printer a must-have device in my house!

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

Nearly solid so that it is strong

Tips If the fit is sloppy in the PVC pipe, wrap the parts in a bit of tape, such as electrical tape or some glossy cellophane tapes, to take up the slack. You don't want them to twist freely. If the fit is too tight, sand the "wedge" parts a little. Optional: sand grooves and edges on the fork holder a little. This will keep rubber bands from snapping over time. For a less industrial look, sand the PVC pipe to get rid of any writing. Print the fork holder and handle in your favorite color or change it with the season. Try fitting it into a piece of bamboo instead of PVC pipe to make it extra classy.

6/29/13 Updated design, fully tested, stronger, more streamlined!
  • Print Fork Handle and Fork Holder.
  • Get a length (I prefer 14", but you can cut it to meet your needs) of 1/2" PVC pipe such as this one on Amazon.com: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003OSFI7U?ie=UTF8&camp=213733&creative=393177&creativeASIN=B003OSFI7U&linkCode=shr&tag=theplamik-20&qid=1360730930&sr=8-5&keywords=pvc+pipe
  • Insert handles, holders, and corresponding "wedges" that print with them.
  • Use a rubber band to secure the fork as pictured.
    • Try it with some forkable foods. It won't work for everything, but things like pieces of fruit, noodles, chunks of meat or tofu, cooked vegetables, and even cut up sandwiches work great. Adjust it to meet your needs. It's not going to be perfect at first. Play with the length of the pipe. Seat height can make a big difference - I like to sit a little higher such as on a stool. Edit the files and print one that works for you! Go somewhere alone and eat in peace and quiet by yourself! Better yet, go on a dinner date, just the two of you. The new-found independence is exciting, and the extended reach will allow you to easily offer to share a bite. Want me to help you design a 3D printable device to meet your needs? Contact me!

Warnings Depending on how you print your parts and what materials you use, your parts may not be food safe and are almost certainly not dishwasher safe. You won't be eating directly off these parts, so that may or may not be important to you. Be careful!

This is a stand designed to hold 50mm diameter lenses for experiments with optics that I designed for my friend Hans who is a teacher. The stand can be clipped onto the edge of a meter stick so that measurements between lenses can easily be made while they stay aligned. The stands can double as feet to support the meter stick, or even holders of a light source such as a flashlight or laser. My unique design even accommodates all thicknesses in a standard pack of lenses such as this one sold on Amazon.com: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00657LW8G?ie=UTF8&camp=213733&creative=393177&creativeASIN=B00657LW8G&linkCode=shr&tag=theplamik-20&qid=1360550742&sr=8-1&keywords=lens+set. This was no small feat! Whether thick or thin, convex or concave, this lens holder will hold them well.

Don't spend hundreds of dollars buying lens stands for your students. This typical Optical Bench like this one (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008DWL9IY/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B008DWL9IY&linkCode=as2&tag=theplamik-20) costs nearly $90! Print these instead.

It also has instructions how to get it to work properly. **Eyecups** for *Oculus Rift DK2* with **IPD** correction (from 64mm to 68mm, +2mm per eye) and **diopter** correction (for VERY roughly -5-dioptre). **No glasses needed anymore** (probably) Oculus Rift DK2 comes with 2 eyecups of different height with identical lenses: - A - height 20mm (for normal sighted) - B - height 17mm (for "moderately" nearsighted) - This - height 10.8mm (for my eyes, adjustments probably will follow) Still testing correct IPD settings and distance in the next days/weeks. *(please ignore the smeary lenses...)*

• Print 2x eyecup & retainer. Use more infill density then I did.
  • Carefully disassemble the original "B" eyecups. Simply use two tiny screw-drivers or similar and lift the retainer ring over one of the 3 snap-in clips.
  • Press out the lenses of the original eyecup.
  • Press in the lenses into the printed eyecup.
  • Press in the retainer ring.
  • Install "right" on the right side.
  • Install "left" on the left side.

title: Thumbscrew for Phillips Flat Head Machine Screw, M5-0.8 x 40mm

description.text:
Having trouble finding the right screws to make other GoPro thumbscrews work? I found stainless steel machine screws M5-0.8 x 40mm on Amazon, but they were too big at the head to work, so I started from scratch to design these thumbscrews. The 25mm design is more like the OEM thumb screw, the 29mm design gives a little more length but uses the same screw. Also included 123D source files in the zip. Find the screws on Amazon here (pack of 25 was $5.45 as of today):
http://www.amazon.com/Stainless-Machine-Finish-Phillips-Threads/dp/B000FN7X3O/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1413227279&sr=8-1&keywords=phillips+flat+head+machine+screw+5mm+40mm

Measured the OEM item.  Designed in Autodesk 123D and printed on Maker's Tool Works Fusematic. Printed at 0.15 layer height in ABS.  Needed raft to be successful for print.  If the screws are little loose, just add a drop of hot glue and drop in the hole.

This fan mount is designed to work with this Sparkfun blower: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11270
It may be overpowered as hell, but with 2 of them in series connected to 12V, I get amazing results from my prints. The fans will reduce the size of your X axis, so it might be best to start with one, even if you have dual extruders. I'm working on a version that will go over the X rods.
Both the mounts and the nozzle can be printed without supports, and if you use a desk fan for cooling you'll get decent overhangs. The nozzle should snap into the mount (may require a bit of effort) and the fan itself slides into the mount and can be secured with zip ties or screws. The mount screws onto the existing screws on the side of the extruder.
